description: From Old French festre (cognate with Italian fistola, Occitan fistola, Spanish fístula), from Latin fistula. The verb is derived from the noun, while the “condition of something that festers” noun sense is derived from the verb. Doublet of fistula.

entries.meaning: (pathology) A sore or an ulcer of the skin.
The condition of something that festers; a festering; a festerment.

verbs.description: fester (third-person singular simple present festers, present participle festering, simple past and past participle festered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become septic; to become rotten.
(intransitive) To worsen, especially due to lack of attention.
examples: Deal with the problem immediately; do not let it fester.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to fester or rankle.
examples: For which I burnt in inward sweltring hate, / And festred rankling malice in my breast, / Till I might belke revenge upon his eyes:  […]
